instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message:
got this board, water damaged , all cleaned now, ppbus im getting only 12.26v, 

i changed isl  , <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>

isl 17/18 = 8 ohm
and pin 27/28= 20 ohm 


any idea why ppbus is not 12.59v


computer turn on with adapter, not with battery

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message: Dead SMC it sounds like. If you plug in the charger and the battery does it give you an "X" for the battery when it boots into the OS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 32260"]Dead SMC it sounds like. If you plug in the charger and the battery does it give you an "X" for the battery when it boots into the OS?[/QUOTE]

yes it showing battery with 100%  and showing x sign on battery

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message: Yeah if the battery is plugged in and the OS is showing an X usually it's either the ISL is bad or the SMC which is more common

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message: I'd do a diode mode reading on pin 2 of both <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> red probe ground black probe pin 2 and see if you get a short. I would guess you will which will be either the ISL or the SMC or (as Louis showed the other day) possibly (highly unlikely) one of the caps on the back bottom left of the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 32263"]I'd do a diode mode reading on pin 2 of both <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> red probe ground black probe pin 2 and see if you get a short. I would guess you will which will be either the ISL or the SMC or (as Louis showed the other day) possibly (highly unlikely) one of the caps on the back bottom left of the board.[/QUOTE]

which caps?  iput new isl still same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message: my qs is why ppbus 12.26v, ? i also took out the fuse f7040, still the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message: PPBUS is 12.26 because the SMC is not running (if it was it would be 12.6). In the case of liquid you want to look at the data lines on <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR>. If either measurement is short, then one of the data lines between the the SMC and the battery are no bueno because either the SMC is dead or has crap under it, the ISL you replaced is bad, or one of the caps attached to those data lines on the back of the board is shorted or bad which is really rare

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> , looks good , which caps attached to those data lines ?

threads.message: Use boardview I don’t remember off the top of my head

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message: And what did you get in diode mode on those resistors?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 32260"]Dead SMC it sounds like. If you plug in the charger and the battery does it give you an "X" for the battery when it boots into the OS?[/QUOTE]

Or the I2C data / clock line is broken, or the battery is fucked. Personally I would bleep out the cock and data lines from 6259 to SMC and then slap a new 6259 on there and test with a good battery WAAAAY before looking at the SMC!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message: He said he replaced the ISL already, so I’m giving him the benefit of the doubt

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message: Did you try a different battery btw? I would hope you did forgot to ask that

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message: YES i tried original apple battery 2 know good one,  , isl is good too , SMC some how not knowing that battery is connected , what to do!!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message: Ok then yes this is a battery recognition issue. If the ISL is good, then it's going to be related to one of the data lines being messed up. We need diode mode readings for <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> to figure out what could be wrong here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board ppbus 12.26v!!!
threads.message:
Give a diode mode reading for pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> with no power going through. Put the red probe on ground, black probe on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR>, and provide measurement in diode mode. Do the same with pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR>.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.23v instead of 12.56v because the SMC is not communicating with the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> as it is supposed to. The SMC uses this same data line to communicate with the battery, so if this does not work then it will not recognize the battery either.

Look at <CAPACITOR>C6952</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6953</CAPACITOR> as well and tell me what they look like.
